pros: Great company, make you feel like your a part of a team
cons: some jealously within the company

review_title: Exploitative, Unappreciative, Unprofessional, Questionalble fund handling strategies, disorganized, management slacks
pros: Some great colleagues to work with if you can take the initiative
cons: This university is filled with fraudulent and manipulative activities. Their administrative standards are of poor quality and can be a huge burden for the employees to navigate when they are trying to contribute high merit intellectual work. Caution must be taken against the hidden truths if you get a job offer and looking for promotion; all they care is money. The management is unappreciative of faculty contribution and only promotes the one they have subjective connection with; the professional standards are fluid and poor quality. An adminstrative strategy employed by the department administrators, under thecollege of liberal arts- Student disruptions (which is a frequent thing in the classroom), lack of discipline, unprofessionalism, miscoduct are covertly supported by the departmental administrator. These misconducts are aggresively promoted among students against the employee; more is done if the employee is a minority compared to the school's majority. Be on lookout for how they handle external funds.

review_title: Pay could be a lot better
pros: Great people to work with.
cons: Pay could be a lot better! Benefits cost share is high!

pros: Great team, great benefits, good students
cons: contract ended and it was hard for further employment

review_title: I worked during President Harvey’s Tenure. I cannot speak to the current state
pros: Hampton prepared you for the next level. You may not get the pay you deserve and are over worked but they prepare you for growth. You learn valuable lessons on workplace politics, becomes extremely efficient at what you do, and build life long relationships.
cons: Hampton’s pay is below industry standard and you are often working more than one position for an extended period of time.

review_title: Higher education with very LOW pay!
pros: Beautiful campus and the people are nice
cons: Pay is terrible and so are the benefits.

review_title: Run Run as far as you can if you have other options
pros: A lot of grant writing opportunities
cons: So much politics. Even if you have research grants, and teaching awards, do your best to help students out, they don't care. Still, old school, do everything on paper, nothing is online. If you are not Black faculty, you are not treated nicely. So much racial discrimination and you are stopped for growth opportunities.

pros: I absolutely love my job at HU. I work in a federally funded office so the day-to-day is a little different than the typical campus department. The staff is like family and the day is never boring.
cons: As it says in the title, everything you've heard is true. The facilities are not taken care of, pay is not stellar (enough to live but not stellar), and just breathing requires ten different forms that twenty different people have to sign before you can do it...

pros: boss was very easy to work with
cons: I was paid once a monthly and pay was not great.

pros: Beautiful Campus , Educational environment
cons:
There is no room for growth at all. paying minimum wage to staff accountant with bachelor degree.
poor management in all levels. My personal opinion it is not a place for long term.

review_title: Will Work You, Won’t Pay You
pros: If you are a good worker you will be treated well as a person.
cons:
Salary doesn’t match the amount of work you have to do.

In my experience there was no room for advancement. The day to day operations are outdated and it doesn’t look like any changes are being made to fix the issues.

Hampton University felt like it operated on an, “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” mentally… but it’s broken.

pros: Good place to work if you do not have much aspiration
cons: Very costly health insurance, pay is not great

review_title: Get In & Get Out in 2yrs or less

cons: Low pay, low support & slow staff.

pros: Diversity, great students, very cultural
cons: Very oppressive environment, top heavy admin

pros: The water is pretty I guess.
cons: Very unorganized and chaotic. I could never get a clear answer when I had questions. The policies were also very weird to me.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Hampton, VA

cons: Everything is difficult, the university runs on a bureaucratic hierarchy and refuses to update systems. Everything is original form paperwork and nothing is electronic. Everything takes 5x longer than it should. Nothing is streamlined.

pros: Weather is good. Experience depends on department you work.
cons: Updates on so many modern things are yet to be up to the level.

pros: Serves the black and other minority community
cons: The school needs to catch with time, it is very old school.

review_title: Working with president Harvey is Amazing
pros: Pleasant University to work for
cons: Some of the Higher uppers in the police Dept are not as pleasant.a lot of favorites on the job

pros: Campus is beautiful, especially in spring.
cons:
Terrible ventilation. Unorganized, outdated systems. Slow processes. Sexually harassed by colleague. Overworked and underpaid. 
Why on earth do you have to physically run time sensitive papers between building so often. Some buildings in dire need of upgrades or repairs but Harvey spent money on a statue of himself that was larger than the statue of president Obama. Wild.

job_title: Director of Development in Hampton, VA
pros: Longevity in staff tenure at the university
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: Its wonderful to work here.
cons: There are no cons of working here.

pros: fantastic relationship with students and faculty
cons: top down hierarchy stifles creativity

pros: Good Law Enforcement career start
cons: Working long hours and nott allowing vacation days

pros: The environment is very relaxed and laid back.
cons: The work conditions and pay is horrible!!!! The leaders are not true leaders and have no awareness of their staff's true feelings about the workplace.

pros: Great location and weather. The university sits on the Chesapeake Bay. The weather is not bad at all. Hot summers and very mild winters.
cons:
The overall attitude of employees was not one to be desired. Students where given a constant run around. Freedom of speech, unless it is approved by the President of the university is not allowed. It has to be a positive tone. On the outside looking in, it has a reputation for great academic value. But the reality is different. Their credits don't transfer to other institutions. Many of my former students couldn't transfer to other institutions because their credits didn't transfer. The only way to achieve that was to leave after your first semester.

They constantly scrambled to regain accreditation for certain programs every summer. The teachers while many were unbiased in their teachings, many still taught a very different story. They were constantly race baiting. It was always the "white man" that was at fault for everything. I have worked at other HBCU institutions and that was not the premise of their education.

The student body took it upon themselves to upload videos to youtube of what is known as the Hampton run-around. The videos were a true to life example of what exist at this institution. it was quickly deleted off youtube. But not before it received thousands of views. The students were reprimanded.

Overall, the school was and can become the great institution that once educated people like Booker T Washington. But unless things change, it will continue to be a stagnant institution .

pros: Beautiful campus; capable colleagues and the potential is unlimited.
cons:
University lacks leadership and there is a culture of mistrust. The  University hasn't automated and most tasks are completed by completing forms and triplicate.  It takes two months to establish a direct direct for your paycheck.  Benefits are basic.  Onboarding is horrific.  HR treats you like a criminal. Before filling out paperwork you must take a drug test that employee must pay for along with your campus parking pass.  The school cafeteria sells heavy foods loaded with fat and grease. You can only take lunch a one hour between the hours of 12-2. Offices do not have heat in the winter or air conditioning in the summer.  You typically use space heaters during the winter months. Many offices lack kitchen facilities or water fountains. Employees are strongly advised to purchase gala tickets to support the Proton Therapy Center rather than find donors to support the center. If you don't have the 200.00 to purchase the ticket, you are offered payroll deduction. Pay deduction is always available to pay for services that the University is selling  You pay for your business cards and will receive a parking ticket if you do not park in your allotted space. Leadership hires their relatives or female favorites and the general perception is that they receive huge paychecks and not held accountable for their work.

If this is how staff is treated, think about the students who are paying over 40K a year to attend school.

pros: students, faculty, teaching, business school, STEM
cons: little opportunities for growth, operations are lacking

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Hampton, VA
pros: diversity, low cost of living
cons: administration, old fashioned system, paper work

review_title: Very little pay  and only get paid twice a semester at uncertain dates
pros: The professors I work with are awesome, my department head is awesome and really great to work with.
cons: You are getting paid much less than you would at other universities in the area. What is more is they don't allow you to sign a contract stating your pay dates until you are weeks into the semester. You will only get paid twice a semester and it is a check, no direct deposit. This is my second semester there and I had to wait 12 weeks to get my first paycheck. My first semester the contract didn't even have the date that they would give me my second check. The contract stated "last working day of the semester"  and I was told they hadn't decided that date yet.

pros: There are great opportunities to learn and grow if you choose.  You are rewarded for going above and beyond. You're also allowed a great amount of autonomy so you can make the position what you want it to be.
cons: Unfortunately there is terrible pay, benefits and incentives, leading to high turnover. The university is very traditional and lacks the cutting edge appeal many younger people seek from an employer.  It's definitely a patriarchal organization.

pros: Excellent work culture, I feel like an integral part of our team.
cons: For the long hours, and going the "extra mile" in my position, I am not compensated well enough for the job that I do. If I were not an alumnus with a vested interest in the university, I would have quit a long time ago. Its sad that I could leave here and make $10,000 more instantly doing the same job at another university. No telework options available.

review_title: EXERCISE EXTREME CAUTION in accepting professorial positions
pros: The students are pretty amazing.
cons: I understand that the academic job market is rough right now, but I do want anyone who chooses to work here to fully understand the environment you'll be walking in to. Faculty have no voice--none. They lure you in with lies so believe nothing they say in your interviews. The tenure requirements are impossible to achieve--must bring in 250k in grants to secure tenure WHILE teaching a 4/4+ load. Loads are supposed to be 4/4 but university is understaffed so end up being 5, 6, 7+ classes a semester. No money for reimbursements for travel/conferences/etc even if they say there is. Expectation is if you're not on campus, you're not working, so forget days where you can work from home. The workload is unsustainable and still it's not enough. Avoid at all costs if you can.

pros: Serving the students and being appreciated by them is rewarding. Work hours are normal. It is a beautiful campus by the bay.
cons: Pay and benefits are horrible. Very little room for pay increase, no upward mobility. You are stuck where you are. Very old school and unorganized. Little electronic processing, everything still via paperwork and slow. Old buildings and furniture. NO resources, financing, or support for anything yet expectations are very high. Connections are everything, if your know someone that works there or have family working there everything gets handed to you.

pros: work at my own pace; no micro-management; abundance of training by hands-on; always challenging figuring out ways to resolve encountered issues with network devices; customers easy to appease; always something to do.
cons: no pay-internship; not enough time was given to learn from the networking personnel aside from new computer lab set ups.

pros: Wondering if you are going to get paid. Hampton is widely known for having problems of paying it's bills on time. Taught summer school one year and got the summer school pay in February.
cons: Manage by making threats against you all the time. That they are going to withhold your pay. Not renew your contract. All of this while paying all the employees, except for the administration, small compensation. Hampton is nor known for paying it's employees competitive salaries. The staff are paid almost nothing for working there. Along with you have to work under constant belittling and a harsh work environment.

pros: Hampton University is situated in a good location..its very peaceful and calm. The campus itself is a very family oriented environment.
cons: I think the only downside is when a storm approaches campus.  I think the administration hesitate on whether to open, close or delay classes.

pros:
-The students and faculty were wonderful. 
-Great insurance
cons:
- Low pay. I knew people in my department making as low as 42K a year as an assistant professor. 
-Faculty have no voice at all, not with the administration. At least in my department, you didn't even have control over content covered in any class.
-Even if your position is technically tenure track, you'll likely never get tenure. It's only possible if you're bringing in huge grants. If you're in a field without big grants, it's not going to happen.
-Rediculous courseloads. You may be told 4/4 when you interview, but, at least in my department and several others, it was mandatory. Teaching up to seven or eight classes a semester happened regularly. 
-You have to do two grants a year and receive them or else you're given a poor review.
-Verbal abuse from higher-ups. 
-You essentially only get Christmas Eve to New Year's Day off for Christmas break. 
-They do 3 different faculty institutes for three weeks of the year, before the year begins, before the second semester, and after the second semester. They're nearly always an absolute waste of time, covering topics that don't apply to all departments. They once brought a speaker that proceeded to bash millennials for their entire time though faculty present were millennials. They in all my years there never once actually told anyone what days they are. It was assumed you'd know. I had to tack down so many new faculty to make sure they actually knew about it.
-There's a lot of committee work
-70+ hour work weeks
-Offices and classrooms without AC, even in summer
-Little to no classroom technology unless you're buying it yourself, yet you are required to use technology or you will receive a poor review. I spent too much money on projectors and the like. 
-Zero professional development 
-The Hampton Run-Around is real. 
-No university credit cards. Places I've worked since providing them to all faculty. The business office keeps very tight control over anything that costs money. If you plan on going to any conferences (I'd be shocked if you were even allowed to go to any) it's out of your own pocket. 
-Access to blackboard for you classes takes weeks
- Dossiers are outrageous. You need 15 letters of recommendation and it'll likely be around a 1000 page document.  You do them regardless of if you're looking to get tenure or not. I also recall the gentleman that was running the whole review thing for them badmouthing past participants something awful. 
-There's a significant amount of paperwork. You have self-assessments, regular write-ups on where you are with writing grants, write-ups on recruitment, and the amount of paperwork you turn in at the end of the semester quite large. 
-Deans don't care at all about their faculty. At my current job, the dean knows me personally. He asks how I'm doing regularly and is all around wonderful. It doesn't have to be like that.
-Anti-LGBTQ. I witnessed a lot of hateful rhetoric. Students were harassed for being LGBTQ.

pros: It was a job lol it kept money in my pockets .
cons: They don't have good equipment they are not oroingzored. Will have you doing multiple things at once and get upset when you can't do everything at one time .

pros: If you are in the right department with a great director, it can be a decent place to work
cons: Students are allowed to treat employees like indentured servants. No IT strategy or growth. A student can curse at an employee and HR will just dismiss it like it was another day at work. The pay is well below standard

review_title: Working with student ,faculty,co-worker from all different countrie and states was  most promising in every aspect.
pros: Youi can work,acheive an education ,meet diferent people from all over,get guidance to move above your own potenial.
cons: Working with someone for an period of time an they pass away,watching the students that you meet  graduate and move on in their lives.

pros: You get to do more than you bargained for. Expect no encouragement. In most cases, the team might be good but please, don't expect too much.
cons: Less pay. More work. The management is bad. Too many disconnect. Your contract may not be renewed or might be canceled in the middle of your job.

pros: The school holds great traditional values.
cons: Get paid once a month. HR treats people like criminals. Stuck in the 80s, no updates. No room for growth. Limits creativity and individuality . Management is EGOTISTICAL, more worried about their personal egos than actually handling the students situations. Expensive parking.  Pay isn’t comparable to other universities in the area. Everything is set up as payroll deduct so they can end up taking money from your check.
